newsitem.title: USA: HOT STOCKS HIGHLIGHTS - U.S. Corporate Earnings.
newsitem.headline: HOT STOCKS HIGHLIGHTS - U.S. Corporate Earnings.

text.p: Shares jumped after the pharmaceutical company posted first quarter earnings per share of $0.81, a penny above estimates of $0.80 compared to $0.72 last year. The company said drug and consumer product sales rose 10 percent, driven by strength in pharmaceutical and consumer products.

Shares rose after the release of first-quarter earnings of $0.90 a share versus $0.78 last year, a penny shy of estimates. But company posted earnings growth despite a slight tail-off in saleas, to $3.60 billion from $3.65 last year.

Shares rose with stock touching a new year high of 100 during intraday trading on Tuesday. Company posted earnings per share of $0.75 compared to $0.79 last year before special items. Analysts had expected $0.76, according to First Call Estimates. It cited poor foreign exchange rates and softness in its consumer businesses for the lower sales and earnings.

Stock was one of the most heavily traded NYSE issues after the Northern Ohio electric utility posted first quarter earnings per share of $0.11, including $0.02 of charges compared to $0.04 a share last year.
Shares the highest percent NYSE gainer, up nearly 13 percent, after the oil and gas company's Q1 net earnings doubled to $0.62 from $0.31 last year.

Shares fell nearly 15 percent after Q1 EPS fell to $0.23 compared to $0.59 last year. Sales fell to $70 million for the quarter from about $81 million in the year-ago period. Stock downgraded by Alex. Brown to market perform from buy.

Playtex share fell six percent after it said Q1 earnings rose to $0.15 from $0.12, or $0.22 compared to $0.18 last year before the amortization of intangibles. But although net income was up 31 percent, in line with estimates, net sales fell five percent, slipping to $136.4 million.
Playtex also said shipments of feminine care products were down 33 percent compared to last year due to its decision to cut back on price-oriented promotional activities.
